poem:
### Legislative Uncorking

In corridors of power,  
whispers swirl—  
a genie slips from its glass,  
shapeshifting into what-may-come.  
As minds weave and stall,  
authority drifts like smoke  
from unclenched fists.  
The Commons, a candle-flame,  
flickers—watch as  
possibilities birth in shadows,  
unknown tomorrows apparent  
in parliament's newly lit hallways.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Welfare climbdown lets genie out of the bottle, and no one knows what happens next A fortnight ago in a corridor near the House of Commons chamber, a close confidant of the prime minister smiled and shook his head when asked if the government could really lose the welfare vote. MPs would come to their senses, he predicted, because they would eventually understand that to fundamentally undermine the government’s authority would have consequences which no". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
